description: Smallest nonnegative integer m such that m! begins with n in base 10.
links: D. Wilson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: Since no factorial below 96! ~ 9.91*10^149 starts with 9, we have a(9) = 96. Similarly, 16 first appears as the leading digits of 89! ~ 1.65*10^136 and hence a(16) = 89. - _Lekraj Beedassy_, Oct 31 2010 and _Robert G. Wilson v_, Nov 05 2010
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[{k = 0, m}, While[ m = Max[0, Floor@ Log[10, k! ] - Floor@ Log[10, n]]; (k! - Mod[k!, 10^m])/10^m != n, k++ ]; k]; Array[f, 67] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Nov 05 2010 *)
prog: (PARI) A018799(n)={ local( F=1,k=0 ); while( F\1!=n, F*=k++; while( F>=n+1, F/=10)); k} \\ _M. F. Hasler_, Feb 01 2009
crossrefs: Apart from leading term, identical to A076219.
author: _David W. Wilson_
